title: R40480
content: The budget reconciliation process is a two-stage procedure that helps Congress adjust revenue, spending, and debt-limit levels to align with the annual budget resolution. Reconciliation directives in the budget resolution instruct committees to develop legislation to achieve desired budgetary outcomes. Compliance is based on the net revenue or spending effects of all changes in the legislation. The budget reconciliation process involves two stages where committees develop legislation to adjust revenue, spending, and debt-limit levels based on the net effects of changes. Instructed committees submit recommendations to Budget Committees, which then incorporate them into an omnibus budget reconciliation bill. If only one committee is instructed, it can report legislation directly to its parent chamber, bypassing the Budget Committee. The budget reconciliation process involves two stages where committees develop legislation to adjust revenue, spending, and debt-limit levels. The House and Senate consider the reconciliation legislation under expedited procedures, with limited debate time and restrictions on amendments. If final agreement on a budget resolution is not reached, the reconciliation process is not triggered. Reconciliation is an optional procedure and has not been used in every year of the congressional budget process. Reconciliation has been used in various years, with the first instance in 1980. In total, Congress has sent 25 reconciliation acts to the President, with 21 being signed into law and three being vetoed by President Clinton. Reconciliation practices in Congress have evolved over the years. Out of the 25 reconciliation acts sent to the President, 21 were signed into law, while President Clinton vetoed three and President Obama vetoed one. The process has seen changes in how spending and revenue changes are handled, with recent years seeing separate reconciliation measures for revenue and spending changes. The Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 brought significant changes in spending and revenues. Reconciliation directives in budget resolutions can lead to multiple measures, with some extending into the following year. For example, the Deficit Reduction Act of 2005 was enacted in 2006. In the FY2010 budget cycle, reconciliation legislation was not considered until 2010, despite the budget resolution being adopted in 2009. The Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 brought significant changes in spending and revenues. A description of 21 reconciliation measures enacted into law is provided in the Appendix, presented in chronological order. The subject areas affected by revenue or spending changes range from specific to broad, with some measures involving proposals from various House and Senate committees. The identified subject areas should be seen as illustrative, not comprehensive. The Omnibus Reconciliation Act of 1980, signed into law by President Jimmy Carter, aimed to reduce the FY1981 deficit by $8.276 billion through spending cuts and revenue increases. It impacted various areas such as child nutrition subsidies, student loan interest rates, federal employee benefits, transportation projects, veterans' benefits, disaster loans, healthcare programs, unemployment compensation, and Social Security. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1981, signed by President Ronald Reagan, aimed to reduce the deficit by $130.6 billion over three years. It included major revenue changes affecting areas such as mortgage subsidy bonds, corporate taxes, and payroll taxes. Major spending changes impacted health program block grants, Medicaid, Food Stamps, and education program block grants. The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982, signed by President Reagan, aimed to increase revenues by $98.3 billion and reduce outlays by $17.5 billion over three years. It impacted areas such as Medicare, Medicaid, AFDC, CSE, SSI, unemployment compensation, and interest payments on U.S. savings bonds. Major revenue changes included the alternative minimum tax, medical and casualty deductions, and pension contribution deductions. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1982, signed by President Reagan, aimed to reduce outlays by $13.3 billion over three years. It impacted areas such as payments to farmers, dairy price supports, Food Stamps, inflation adjustments for federal retirees, and lump-sum premiums for Federal Housing. Major revenue changes included deductions, pension contributions, FICA tax for Medicare coverage, accelerated depreciation, investment tax credits, corporate tax payments, foreign oil and gas income, and corporate tax preferences. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1983, signed in 1984, aimed to reduce the deficit by $8.2 billion over four years. It included changes such as delaying federal employee pay raises, retirement COLAs, veterans' compensation COLAs, and providing disaster loans for farmers. Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 (P.L. 99-272) was estimated to reduce the deficit by $18.2 billion over three years, covering FY1986-FY1988. Major spending changes affected student loans, highway spending, veterans' medical care, Medicare, Medicaid, and trade adjustment assistance. Major revenue changes included the cigarette tax, excise taxes for the Black Lung Trust Fund, unemployment tax exemptions, taxation of railroad retirement benefits, airline employee income taxation, and deduction of research expenses for multinational firms. The Budget Reconciliation Act of 1986 (P.L. 99-509) aimed to reduce the deficit by $11.7 billion over FY1987-FY1989, avoiding a sequester. Major spending changes impacted Medicare, Medicaid, agricultural support, federal employee retirement, and Social Security COLAs. Revenue changes included tax treatment of Conrail sale, import fees, tax penalties, foreign tax credits denial. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987 (P.L. 100-203) was the final reconciliation measure signed by President Reagan, covering the period of FY1988-FY1990. It implemented $76 billion in deficit reduction over FY1988 and FY1989, following a budget summit agreement reached after a stock market decline in October. Major spending changes affected areas such as Medicare, Medicaid, agricultural support, federal employee retirement payments, Postal Service contributions, Guaranteed Student Loan program, Nuclear Regulatory Committee fees, and National Park funding. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989, signed into law by President George H. W. Bush, aimed to reduce the deficit by $14.7 billion. Major revenue changes included adjustments to home mortgage interest deduction, mutual fund expenses deduction, and corporate estimated tax payments. Spending changes affected areas such as Medicare, Medicaid, veterans' housing loans, and agricultural support. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990, P.L. 101-508, implemented deficit reduction measures for FY1991-FY1995 following a budget summit at Andrews Air Force Base. It included changes to various programs and revenue areas such as employer-provided education assistance, low-income housing credit, and research and experimentation credits. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 aimed to reduce the deficit by $482 billion over five years through revenue increases and spending cuts. Major changes affected programs like Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security, and various revenue areas including individual income tax rates and excise taxes on alcoholic beverages and tobacco products. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993, signed by President Bill Clinton, aimed to reduce the deficit by $496 billion over five years through revenue increases and spending cuts. Major changes affected areas such as Medicare, Medicaid, student loan programs, and agricultural price supports. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996, covering FY1997-FY2002, aimed to reduce the deficit by $54.6 billion. Major changes included temporary assistance for needy families, work requirements, restrictions on benefits for illegal aliens, and child nutrition programs. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997, signed by President Clinton, aimed to reduce the deficit by $118 billion over five years through spending cuts and revenue reductions. It impacted areas such as Medicare, Medicaid, children's health initiative, Food Stamps, TANF, SSI, and veterans' housing. The public debt limit was increased from $5.5 trillion to $5.95 trillion. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 and the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 were significant reconciliation measures that included various revenue provisions such as tax credits, education incentives, capital gains tax cuts, and corporate tax changes. These acts aimed to provide tax relief and stimulate economic growth during the specified fiscal years. President George W. Bush's tax-cut agenda during his first year in office reduced the projected surplus by $1.349 trillion over FY2001–FY2011. The tax cuts affected individual income tax rates, the "marriage penalty," child tax credit, estate and gift taxes, retirement accounts, charitable contributions, education incentives, health insurance tax credit, and more. The tax cuts were set to expire in 10 years to comply with Senate rules. The Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003, estimated to reduce revenues by $349.667 billion over 11 years, included changes such as tax reductions, bonus depreciation, taxes on dividends and capital gains, and special estimated tax rules. The Reduction Act of 2005 P.L. 109-171, signed by President George W. Bush in 2006, aimed to reduce the deficit by $38.810 billion over five years. It impacted areas like Medicare, Medicaid, SCHIP, student loans, digital television conversion, and agricultural conservation programs. Tax Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act of 2005 P.L. 109-222 was the revenue reconciliation bill enacted in 2006, estimated to increase the deficit by $69.960 billion over five years. Major revenue changes included tax rates on dividends and capital gains, alternative minimum tax for individuals, and withholding on government payments. The College Cost Reduction and Access Act of 2007 and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 were reconciliation acts that aimed to reduce the deficit and make changes to student loan programs and healthcare laws. The reconciliation act of 2017, P.L. 115-97, included changes to the tax code and directed the Secretary of the Interior to implement an oil and gas leasing program. It aimed to reduce the deficit by $143 billion over 10 years. The reconciliation act of 2017, P.L. 115-97, included changes to the tax code such as reducing most individual income tax rates, modifying tax brackets, increasing standard deduction and child tax credit, repealing deductions for personal exemptions, and permanently repealing penalties for the individual mandate. It also made permanent modifications to business taxation, including a flat 21% corporate tax rate and a 20% reduction for pass-through businesses. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 included changes to the tax code, such as reducing individual income tax rates, increasing standard deduction, and implementing a flat 21% corporate tax rate. It also provided a 20% reduction for pass-through businesses and directed the Secretary of the Interior to implement an oil and gas leasing program in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The legislation was estimated to increase the deficit by $1.46 trillion over the 2018-2027 period.
